title: How to Recognize Signs of Dyslexia

steps.title: Look for difficulties in talking and hearing.
steps.content: Look for difficulties in talking and hearing. Dyslexia is characterized by problems decoding and processing language, so symptoms will appear in areas other than just reading. [3] X Research source One or two symptoms is not necessarily indicative of dyslexia, but if your child has many of these symptoms, you may want to speak with your child's pediatrician. Delayed speech (though this can have many other causes). Consult your pediatrician if you are concerned about your child's speech development. [4] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Difficulty pronouncing words, including letter switching – i.e. “mawn lower” instead of “lawn mower.” [5] X Research source Difficulty breaking down words into sounds as well as the reverse, the ability to blend sounds to make words when speaking. [6] X Research source Difficulty with rhyming words together. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Look for learning difficulties.
steps.content: Look for learning difficulties. Because children with dyslexia have difficulty with phonological processing (the manipulation of sounds) and rapid visual-verbal responding, they may exhibit some difficulties in basic learning, including: [8] X Research source Slowness to build their vocabulary. Usually dyslexic pre-school children only say a small number of words. [9] X Research source Slow recall of sounds, letters, colors, and numbers. Dyslexic children may also be slow to name even objects familiar to them. [10] X Research source Difficulty in recognizing their own names. [11] X Research source [12] X Research source Annual Research Review: The Nature and Classification of Reading Disorders--A Commentary on Proposals for DSM-5 (Margaret J Snowling & Charles Hulme) in Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry 53(5), May 2012, pp. 593-607. Difficulty rhyming or reciting nursery rhymes. Difficulty remembering content, even from a favorite video. Note that writing errors are not necessarily indicative of dyslexia in pre-schoolers. Many kindergarteners and first-graders reverse their letters and numbers as they are just learning to write. However, this can be a sign of dyslexia in older children and if the reversal of letters and numbers in writing persists, your child should be tested for dyslexia. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Look for physical difficulties.
steps.content: Look for physical difficulties. Because dyslexia includes problems with spatial organization and fine motor control, it can also have physical manifestations in young children, including: [14] X Research source Slowness to develop fine motor skills, such as holding a pencil, book, using buttons and zippers, or brushing teeth. [15] X Research source [16] X Research source Difficulty knowing left from right. [17] X Research source Difficulty moving to the rhythm with music. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Talk to your child’s pediatrician.
steps.content: Talk to your child’s pediatrician. If you are concerned that your child might have dyslexia, it's best to consult with your child's primary physician. Early diagnosis is vital in helping children learn to cope effectively with dyslexia. Professionals have a battery of tests that allow them to test and diagnose dyslexia in children as young as 5 years old.

steps.title: Look for difficulty reading.
steps.content: Look for difficulty reading. Dyslexia among children and young people is usually first recognized when they fall behind their peers in learning to read or in consistently reading below their age level. This is the primary indicator of dyslexia. [19] X Research source Dyslexia: Its Impact of the Individual, Parents and Society (Lamk Al-Lamki) in Sultan Qaboos University Medical Journal 12(3), August 2012, pp. 269-272. Reading problems may include: [20] X Research source A delay in learning the connection between letters and sounds. [21] X Research source The confusion of small words like “at” and “to” or “does” and “goes”. Consistent reading, spelling, and writing errors, even after being shown the correct forms. [22] X Research source Common errors include letter reversals (e.g., “d” for “b”); word reversals (e.g., "tip" for "pit"); inversions (e.g., “m” for “w” and “u” for “n”); transpositions (e.g., “felt” and “left”); substitutions (e.g., "house" and "home”). [23] X Research source Needing to read a short selection multiple times to comprehend it. [24] X Research source Dyslexia: Its Impact of the Individual, Parents and Society (Lamk Al-Lamki) in Sultan Qaboos University Medical Journal 12(3), August 2012, pp. 269-272. [25] X Research source Trouble understanding age-appropriate concepts. [26] X Research source Dyslexia: Its Impact of the Individual, Parents and Society (Lamk Al-Lamki) in Sultan Qaboos University Medical Journal 12(3), August 2012, pp. 269-272. Trouble taking notes and predicting what will happen next in a story or sequence.

steps.title: Watch for auditory (listening) and speech problems.
steps.content: Watch for auditory (listening) and speech problems. The underlying cause of dyslexia is a problem with phonological processing, the ability to see or hear a word, break it down into discrete sounds, and then associate each sound with the letters that make up the word. [27] X Research source Though this makes reading particularly difficult, it often also impacts children's ability to listen and speak clearly and correctly. [28] X Research source Signs include: Problems comprehending rapid instructions or recalling sequences of commands. Difficulty remembering what is heard. Difficulty putting thoughts into words. [29] X Research source The child may also speak in halting sentences and leave sentences incomplete. [30] X Research source Garbled speech: wrong words or similar words substituted for what the child means. Difficulty making and comprehending rhymes. [31] X Trustworthy Source National Institutes of Health U.S. government agency for biomedical and public health research Go to source

steps.title: Watch for physical symptoms.
steps.content: Watch for physical symptoms. Because dyslexia includes problems with spatial organization, dyslexic children may also struggle with their motor skills. Common signs of problems with motor skills include: [32] X Research source Trouble with writing or copying. Their handwriting may also be illegible. Frequent confusion of left and right, over and under.

steps.title: Look for emotional or behavioral signs.
steps.content: Look for emotional or behavioral signs. Children with dyslexia often struggle in school, particularly as they see their peers reading and writing with relative ease. As a result, these children may feel less intelligent or like they have failed in some way. [33] X Research source There are a number of emotional and behavioral signs that may indicate that your child is suffering from a lack of diagnosis and treatment of dyslexia: The child expresses low self-esteem. [34] X Research source Dyslexia: Its Impact of the Individual, Parents and Society (Lamk Al-Lamki) in Sultan Qaboos University Medical Journal 12(3), August 2012, pp. 269-272. [35] X Research source The child becomes withdrawn or depressed and is not interested in socializing or being together with friends. [36] X Research source The child experiences anxiety. Some experts consider anxiety to be the most frequent emotional symptom exhibited by dyslexic children. [37] X Research source Dyslexia: Its Impact of the Individual, Parents and Society (Lamk Al-Lamki) in Sultan Qaboos University Medical Journal 12(3), August 2012, pp. 269-272. The child expresses extreme frustration, which often manifests itself in anger. [38] X Research source Dyslexia: Its Impact of the Individual, Parents and Society (Lamk Al-Lamki) in Sultan Qaboos University Medical Journal 12(3), August 2012, pp. 269-272. The child may also exhibit troubling behavior, including "acting out", in order to take attention away from his learning difficulty. [39] X Research source The child may have difficulty keeping focused and seems "hyper" or a "daydreamer." [40] X Research source

steps.title: Watch for avoidance mechanisms.
steps.content: Watch for avoidance mechanisms. Children and young adults with dyslexia may deliberately try to avoid situations where they have to read, write or speak in a public capacity in front of their peers, teachers, and parents. Be aware that older children in particular often use coping or avoidance strategies. What looks like poor organization or even laziness may be a way to avoid the difficulties associated with dyslexia. [41] X Research source Children and young people may feign illness in order to get out of reading out loud or public speaking for fear of embarrassment. They may also procrastinate on reading and writing assignments in order to put off their struggle for as long as possible.

steps.title: Speak to your child’s teacher and doctor.
steps.content: Speak to your child’s teacher and doctor. If you think your child may have dyslexia based on any of the above signs, it is imperative that you consult those who are also invested in your child, like his teacher and his primary care physician. These individuals can help guide you to the right psychological professional so that your child can be formally tested. Early diagnosis is important in helping children learn to cope with dyslexia. Unmet needs in dyslexic children can have dire consequences for these children later in life. Studies have shown that more than one-third of students with dyslexia drop out of high school, which accounts for more than one-quarter of all high school drop-outs. [42] X Research source Dyslexia: Its Impact of the Individual, Parents and Society (Lamk Al-Lamki) in Sultan Qaboos University Medical Journal 12(3), August 2012, pp. 269-272. No one test can diagnose dyslexia. The standard battery of tests includes up to sixteen separate assessments. They examine all aspects of the reading process to see where the difficulties are occurring, compare reading level to reading potential based on intelligence, and test how students are most comfortable absorbing and reproducing information (audibly, visually, or kinetically). [43] X Research source Tests are usually set up through the child’s school but for additional help, you can find a list of dyslexia centers and professionals by state here .

steps.title: Look for problems related to reading and writing.
steps.content: Look for problems related to reading and writing. Adults who have long lived with dyslexia often struggle with many of the same problems as children. Common signs of reading and writing difficulties among adults include: [44] X Research source Reading slowly and with many inaccuracies. Poor spelling. Dyslexics may also spell the same word multiple ways in a single piece of writing. Inadequate vocabulary. Difficulty with planning and organization, including outlining and summarizing information. Poor memory skills and trouble storing information after reading.

steps.title: Look for coping strategies.
steps.content: Look for coping strategies. Many adults will have developed coping strategies to compensate for their dyslexia. [45] X Research source Annual Research Review: The Nature and Classification of Reading Disorders--A Commentary on Proposals for DSM-5 (Margaret J Snowling & Charles Hulme) in Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry 53(5), May 2012, pp. 593-607. [46] X Research source A New Self-Report Inventory of Dyslexia For Students: Criterion and Construct Validity (P. Tamboer, H.S. Vorst) in Dyslexia 21(1), February 2015, pp. 1-34. These strategies include: [47] X Research source Avoiding reading and writing. Relying on others to spell. Procrastinating on reading and writing tasks. Relying on memory rather than reading.

steps.title: Note the presence of some above-average skills.
steps.content: Note the presence of some above-average skills. Even though dyslexics may have difficulty reading, this is not indicative of a lack of intelligence. [48] X Research source In fact, dyslexics often have outstanding "people skills" and are very intuitive and effective at reading others. They also tend to have strong spatial thinking skills and may work in fields requiring these skills such as engineering and architecture. [49] X Research source

steps.title: Get tested.
steps.content: Get tested. Once identified as dyslexic, adults can learn strategies to become more effective readers and writers; this, in turn, may increase their self-esteem. [50] X Research source Speak to a medical professional to find a professional (usually a psychologist) to administer the appropriate tests.
